  • Validate query

Single Query


Takes one ID or entity name as input. Finds all the entities that the input directly targets. This means that there is a relationship between the input and the entity such that the input affects the entity. If desired, this algorithm can go to additional depths by finding the entities directly affected by the entities that are directly affected by the input. There is the option to drop relationships that do not show up in many papers. For every relationship that is found, the algorithm checks if there is a relationship going in the opposite direction. If there is, the algorithm outputs the reverse relationship no matter how many papers support it.

Takes the following inputs:


  1. One ID or entity name

  2. Depth (integer between 1 and 4, inclusive): Specifies the number of “layers” to go out from the query. For example, depth of 1 means that the algorithm will find the entities that the query directly targets. Depth of 2 means that the algorithm will find the entities that the query directly targets, and the entities that the first “layer” directly targets.

  3. Minimum literary presence for the first layer (non-negative integer): The query algorithm can drop links between entities that are not supported by enough papers. This number specifies the minimum number of papers that a link must have in order to not be dropped.

  4. Minimum literary presence for subsequent layers (non-negative integer): Same as minimum literary presence for the first layer. For queries of depth greater than 2, it is recommended that this number be around 100-200 because the number of entities and relationships increases greatly with each depth. With a lot of entities, the visualization becomes very large, and it is difficult to gain information from looking at it. If the visualization is too large, it is recommended to increase this number.

Single Query Example - Senescence (MeSH ID: D000375)

Zoom in by scrolling, mouseover nodes to see immediate outgoing connections

Multi Query


Takes a comma-separated list of IDs or entity names as input. Finds shortest paths between these entities. Essentially, the algorithm finds all possible pair combinations within the list. Then, it finds the shortest path in both directions (if it exists) between all pairs. The user can specify the maximum number of linkers that a path can contain. For example, if the algorithm is trying to find a path between entity 1 and entity 2, and the maximum number of linkers is 1, the algorithm will first try to find entity 2 from everything directly connected to entity 1. If entity 2 is not found, the algorithm will try to find entity 2 from everything directly connected to the entities directly connected to entity 1, but look no further than that.

Takes the following inputs:


  1. A comma-separated list of IDs or entity names.

  2. The maximum number of linkers between two entities (non-negative integer).

Multi Query Example - Shortest path between various types of lipids

Zoom in by scrolling, mouseover nodes to see immediate outgoing connections
